title: Pawnce on why riot nerfs instead of buffs

embed.description: http://www.Twitch.tv/Pawnce or http://www.lifeintheleague.com/livestream Livestream every week day. Follow http://www.Twitter.com/Pawnce_LoL for my schedule.

replies.body:
The problem isn't so much with the concept of nerfing champions to balance them, but rather that Riot doesn't execute it properly.
Champions ends up in an OP - UP - Underplayed - OP cycle. (ie. Talon)

Even worse, besides some of the LCS Big Plays champions, anyone that Riot nerfs will most often end up being below average in his/her respective category. Early in the video, Pawnce described how buffing other champions to a higher power level can create more problematic champions; well, the same applies when we nerf them. 

The most famous example is Zed. Zed wasn't among the top contenders in mid lane, let alone the entire game until all his competition was nerfed into oblivion. LB, Kass, Ahri and Talon all had much better combos than Zed before Riot brought out the nerf hammer. By gradually lowering the power budget of champions through nerfs, previously "balanced" champions becomes unbalanced not because they are better, but rather because that everyone else is now terrible.

The argument against buffing other champions only works if the particular OP champion in question is miles ahead of the rooster. (ie. LB or Kass) Otherwise, if the difference is marginal, nerfing him/her will only have another take its place as the best champion. 

 Azir isn't even the best mid laner. Nerfing him just shoehorns people into even better champions such as Zed or Orianna for mid lane.

No one is advocating that Riot should only buff champions to balance them, but rather to just stop with the nerfs.

Power seep isn't a term,power seep makes no sense.

buffs(and nerfs) have little to nothing to do with power creep,people just misuse the term.

from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_creep

Power creep is the gradual unbalancing of a game due to successive releases of new content.[1] The phenomenon may be caused by a number of different factors and, in extreme cases, can be damaging to the longevity of the game in which it takes place.

As new expansions or updates are released, new game mechanics or effects are introduced, making it increasingly difficult for older content to remain in balance without changes. Usually, this means new content releases grow successively more powerful while older content becomes regressively outdated or relatively underpowered.

This term is used outside games as well.[2][3]

There's a reason riot refers to the current mobility spam as "mobiltiy creep",because it's a specific case of power creep where power is creeping through mobility.

Actually. You and your use of the internet to prove me wrong make a lot of sense.

That is why I worded it as a question because I wasn't sure.

As new champions are released, item changes, etc. some champions will become better than others naturally (ie Liandries buff would make Brand op  somehow and the best mid laner in the game by far).  This is called power creep.  The power of champions is slowly creeping up higher and higher and higher which pushes out other champions from viability.  For example, if power creep in this game was very low you would see a ton of Anivia, Malz, Urgot, etc. in pro play but power creep has completely pushed them out of the game.

Exactly. 
It's not the fact that Riot is nerfing because a champion is "OP", or "Toxic".  It's because they nerf champions based on the professional scene.  Where Professionals know how to abuse the targeted champions strengths it gives that champion a blanket called "OP".  The system for balancing in this game is completely flawed because it's just a cycle of nerfs and buffs to who ever fits in the meta slot the easiest and the best possible way.  You'd see Urgot in the professional play because of his range and what the meta calls for.  It doesn't mean said champion is OP, but just abusable by professionals who seek that attribute when playing a champion; AKA "Tristana".  Tristan is a clear example of this, and how this system is completely convoluted in every way.

Poor video as it overtly over generalize his theory by the extreme. He assumes that we want everybody to be OP like Azir, which is literally not the case. We want champions to get buffed IN COMPENSATION for their lack of utility and mobility. By nerfing everyone, you are letting champions that have superior utilities prevail in every way shape and form. By buffing them, you are letting champions be on equal footing but having a certain characteristic or abilities that stands from the rest. Having that said ability desirable. 

There is a reason why that around 30% of the champion pool gets selected **consistently** in the pro scene. 

The result of nerfing becomes this: Why would I pick X  champion (Shen, Ashe, Xin, Taric, Lux) when Y champion (Sion, Jinx, J4, Leona, Xereth) does his job but better?

Say they buff another champion like you say. Now that could push out 10 other champions. Causing more to need to get buffed. This is where the power creep comes from. 

Shen is still balanced around S3. When he could push one lane, let an inhib lane push another and the other 4 of his team pushes another. Since split pushing was nerfed mechanically in S4 his niche got much smaller. 

Ashe is a team ADC. She's strong with communication. Since the supports that augmented her(and Varus) were nerfed/pushed out she sees less play. But what she does is still strong. She just can't handle Braum/Thresh/Leona/Annie being able to dive her so well. Riot's goal this season is to make more ways to win viable. Ashe/Varus + Zyra/Nami could see a return if they make it happen. 

Xin needs a mini-rework. His kit front loads too much too fast. It gives very little counterplay unless you have mobility. In which you can completely counter him. Since everything he does is overall AA based with one gap closer. He's just outdated ATM.

Taric is stronger than he seems. He works better with communication as he needs teams to follow up on his stun ASAP. I think he should get a rework as well. Something that pushes him out of support and into other lanes. Just because a champion can heal others doesn't mean they should be forced into support. It would make a very interesting jungler setup. Being able to walk into lane and possibly gank. If not heal your allies before returning. 

Lux isn't really weak. As long as we don't bring up mana-less champions anyway. She needs tweaks to help her mana costs. But overall that's mostly it. 

30% of the champion pool sees play in pro games because they tend to play only a few kind of metas. Which those 30 champions excel in. It's not about one champion being stronger. It's about one champion being stronger at a type of gameplay. Lux vs Xerath, Lux bring more reliable CC and a shield. If you wanted that from your mid lane for some reason you would pick Lux. She's also better at picking off enemies with a QER combo. If we could make Lux as good as Xerath at what Xerath does, why take Xearth when Lux can be Xerath with better CC and a team-wide shield.

> [{quoted}](name=Cindikle,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=94MzObJr,comment-id=00060000,timestamp=2015-02-11T22:11:08.058+0000)

Balancing mana champions around manaless champions should just not be done, otherwise they start outperforming their fellow mana champions. There are only a few manaless midlaners (and really only Kata, Yasuo and Zed are played currently) while all the rest are mana users. Buffing mana costs to compete with champions who don't use mana is an indication of manaless champions not paying for being manaless.

> Lux vs Xerath, Lux bring more reliable CC and a shield. If you wanted that from your mid lane for some reason you would pick Lux. She's also better at picking off enemies with a QER combo. If we could make Lux as good as Xerath at what Xerath does, why take Xearth when Lux can be Xerath with better CC and a team-wide shield.

Lux has a root, Xerath has a stun. Both have aoe spells with slows. Xerath, like Lux, has a way of picking off running targets. But what Xerath also has is spammable mini Lux ults while Lux really only has 2 damaging spells on high cd aside from her ult. He simply outclasses her, but not because she's weak, but because he's currently broken. They're both ridiculously safe, except Xerath is a ridiculously safe dps mage, which is preferable.

Balancing mana can mean more than just buffs to the cost. It could mean she gets a way to restore mana with abilities. I think a 5% max mana return on procing her passive(once per spell cast) would be perfect. It is much weaker than Xerath's for comparison. And it requires her to spend mana as well as use AA's(thus cannot be passive). It would also allow building mana as a form of mana return instead of mana regeneration an option. If you don't plan on stacking CDR for some reason you can get a tear and do quite well. Or just have other options(Twin Shadows for example). 

Far as comparing their kits. Lux has a shield that hits the whole team. Her slow is much more effective and harder to dodge. And doesn't require hitting them in the center to be mostly effective. Her snare can hit two targets(although weaker for the second). And Xerath's Q can be very easy to side step. Not saying Lux's R is hard to step out of, but it is harder to do so. 

I wouldn't really call Xerath a dps mage. He's a poke mage. A lot of what he does is easily readable. It has plenty of counterplay. Lux gives up some stuff that Xerath has because she has more utility and her CC is more reliable.

Yeah, no. Lux is in a very good position compared to the majority of mages with much worse mana costs and much less utility and safety. Xerath is just broken currently.
Lux most of the time does play passive. Every spell of hers has 1000> range. Passive is hardly necessary for her to use. If you want buffs to her, then nerf her ridiculous safety so she actually has a reason to come closer than 1000 units.
Mana got nerfed all across the board. That's what should be looked at, not some mage who's in a pretty good position compared to others.

***sigh*** You forget, dota doesn't 100% do nothing but buff. There are also nerfs. Say something is a 11 and other heroes are say a 8, icefrog turns the 11 a 10 by either making weakness WAY more apparent or toning strengths down. and the 8 into a 9 or 10. For example, take Faceless Void. He used to be NEVER played and received nothing but buffs and buffs. Then he started seeing play in 6.82 in the offlane. (Traditionally he was only played as one of the hardest carries in the safelane with a support). 

He hadn't been nerfed in forever (unless you count the rescaling cd BUT increased slow per level of his Q in 6.66 as a nerf) and still wasn't played. THEN when he did finally get play he wasn't nerfed in his offlaning ways. He only had his weaknesses made more glaring. He was a bit mana starved when it came to His ult, Q, and using Mask of Madness so how does he get nerfed? First round of nerfs, ult no longer stopped passives (meaning you could counter with evasion), still strong but now he had to buy an item to counter evasion instead of having his ult do it for him. Next nerfs were minor cd increase, (however his agh's ((which most pros got at the time) was untouched), a nerf to some combo potential, a nerf to dueling potential with his Q, and finally, a mana cost increase which hurt. 


Riot balancing this? I could see something along the lines of nerf strength and weaknesses, and go overboard massivly so he wouldn't see play until everybody was nerfed to his level say, ult reduction at all levels, cooldown increase, AND nerf his core items. Like personally, I do see the advantages in nerf nerf nerf (even though I HEAVILY criticize it), but then it's just kinda depressing that everything gets brought down only for another champ to take its place because they haven;t been nerfed yet.  And yes I do enjoy both games, but I just like one's design philosophy better than another. I'm sure you can tell which from this story I've written.
